s.text: Since art is infinitely various and complex, it's particularly implausible that anyone else would have written Shakespeare's plays.
(JP II and Reagan, by contrast, showed up too late to get much consideration.)
This triathlon kills Churchill, who wins the defeat-totalitarianism contest but flunks the liberation-and-justice contest.
And second, if you check the stats, Stalin and Mao actually killed more people.

This is how George Will justifies his selection of William Shakespeare as man of the millennium, while dismissing scientists on the grounds that "science has its own logic and is going to get where it's going," regardless of which scientist gets there first.

What better way to validate a great man than to quote another great man calling him a great man?

If your nominee showed up later, stress the immediacy of his achievements, since most people can relate to today's breakthroughs and gizmos and have forgotten those from the first half of the century.
